I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the City Region Development Project. The report 
also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  grants  for  (i)  Strengthening  Regional 
Planning and Governance, and (ii) Energy Efficiency Improvement, and if the Board approves 
the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the 
TAs. 
 
2.  The project1 aims to increase growth potential and environmental sustainability of two 
city regions based on coherent regional urban planning. A city region is defined as an organic 
agglomeration of a large city, surrounding secondary towns, and adjacent peri-urban areas. The 
project will target the city regions of Dhaka and Khulna.2 It will support the development of key 
urban infrastructure, focusing on urban environment and local economic development. The 
project  also  supports  government  efforts  to  improve  regional  and  urban  planning,  and  to 
strengthen  municipal  management  and  capacity  for  effective  and  sustainable  urban 
development. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Urbanization  in  Bangladesh.  Bangladesh  has  urbanized  very  rapidly  and  its 
frameworks of urban planning and development are not capable to meet the evolving demands. 
Growing at current rates, the country’s urban population is estimated to double by 2035 and 
reach  74  million.3  In  the  course  of  this  rapid  urbanization,  a  large  city  (city  corporation), 
surrounding secondary towns (pourashavas), and adjacent peri-urban areas (urban centers) 
have been agglomerating into a city region with close economic and social links.4 However, while 
effectively one sprawling city, it is still administered by multiple municipal governments. Because a 
comprehensive  framework  for  integrated  planning  and  coordination  among  municipalities  is 
lacking,  the  city  regions  have  been  unable  to  realize  their  full  development  potential. 
Implementation of the Dhaka Metropolitan Development Plan (DMDP) (1995–2015) has been 
very slow, and the plan is fast becoming outdated. Rajdhani Unnayan Kartripakkha (RAJUK)5 led 
the preparation of the DMDP, and there are criticisms that it did not sufficiently consult with the 
public and the municipalities. Private and public development projects are not always coordinated 
enough to focus limited resources on priority areas.  
 
4.  The project will support improvement of urban planning through a review and update of 
the  urban  development  plans,  notably  the  DMDP,  and  strengthen  coordination  between 
municipalities and planning agencies. The DMDP and municipal development plans will be 
updated in a consistent manner to establish a coherent regional development framework. The 
project will support the implementation of the DMDP through feasibility studies and investment 
in key infrastructure. An associated TA, Strengthening Regional Planning and Governance, will

responsible for urban planning in the Dhaka city region.

2 
review the institutional framework for regional planning and governance to rationalize urban 
planning and development control.  
 
5.  Municipal infrastructure and services. The development of urban infrastructure has 
not kept pace with the rapid urbanization. Combined with ineffective planning and control, 
inadequate infrastructure causes environmental degradation, and restricts economic and social 
activities.  In  Dhaka,  pollution  of  water  bodies  caused  by  limited  sewerage  and  poor 
maintenance of sanitation facilities such as septic tanks has become a serious concern. In 
Khulna, floods and water logging severely restrict local economic activities in monsoon season. 
Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of flooding. Piped water is 
available only in the city center, and water service is poor in most pourashavas. Lack of access 
to water and sanitation facilities imposes a particular burden on women, who are primary 
caretakers of household health. Available transport infrastructure cannot cope with growing 
traffic  volumes,  and  traffic  flows  are  further  limited  by  poor  traffic  management,  such  as 
uncontrolled roadside parking. Poor roadside conditions adversely affect pedestrians, most of 
which are women and the poor.   
 
6.  Municipalities  have  not  been  able  to  address  these  issues  for  lack  of  human  and 
financial resources. The few interventions are reactive, responding only to the immediate needs, 
without a coordinated strategy for effective investments. The project will enhance the capacity of 
the infrastructure that is best suited to improve the urban environment and stimulate the local 
economy. The project takes a sector approach, and subprojects will be prioritized to ensure 
coherent  regional  development.  Although  municipalities  tend  to  be  constrained  by  limited 
capacity, some have achieved remarkable improvements through recent projects such as the 
Urban Governance and Infrastructure Improvement (Sector) Project (UGIIP).6 The key lesson 
learned from the UGIIP is that performance-based allocation of investment funds creates strong 
incentives, and substantial improvement can be achieved if it is combined with appropriate 
capacity building programs.7 Based on these achievements and lessons learned, the project will 
adopt performance-based allocation of investment funds. The flexibility of a sector loan will 
allow municipalities to compete with each other to secure the investment funds, creating strong 
incentive to meet the performance targets. The capacity-building programs will follow the UGIIP 
programs  and  particularly  help  new  municipalities  achieve  performance  targets.  Project 
implementation will be more expeditious than previously possible since many implementing 
agencies have strengthened their capacity under the UGIIP.8 
 
7.  Climate change. Municipalities are not well prepared to adapt to the expected impacts 
of climate change, and unaware of the potential benefits of energy efficiency. Since Bangladesh 
is one of the countries most vulnerable to climate change impacts, policy and advisory TA for 
Strengthening  Resilience  of  the  Water  Sector  in  Khulna  to  Climate  Change9  has  been 
conducted to assess the potential impacts and explore adaptation measures. Urban planning 
and key infrastructure in Khulna, notably drainage, will reflect these findings. The project will 
support the municipalities in improving the energy efficiency of streetlights and water pumps,

which account for most of their energy consumption. Municipalities operate water pumps of very 
low  efficiency,  and  streetlights  are  fitted  with  inefficient  fluorescent  tubes,  implying  large 
potential to save energy and cut carbon dioxide (CO ) emission. Since energy costs account for 
2
a large share of municipalities' recurrent expenditures, higher energy efficiency can substantially 
improve municipal finances.  
 
8.  Context in country programming. The project is designed in line with ADB’s country 
strategy and program (2006–2010).10 Urban development is a focus area of the country strategy 
and program, and the project will directly contribute to the key outcomes of social development 
and sustainable economic growth. Since the long-term investment requirements of the project’s 
city  regions  are  very  large,  the  project  will  (i)  directly  fund  crucial  infrastructure  and  (ii) 
complement ongoing and planned future projects.11 Its design also reflects lessons learned from 
previous  interventions  and  takes  into  account  recommendations  of  the  sector  program 
assistance evaluation.12 The project will invest in multiple municipalities within the two city 
regions, engaging them constructively in the establishment of a coherent regional development 
plan. The DMDP update and the preparation of feasibility studies will result in a clear road map 
to support a long-term engagement and pinpoint the need for future projects.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  enhanced  growth  potential  and  environmental 
sustainability of the two city regions. The outcome will be improved urban environment and 
infrastructure services based on effective regional and urban planning.  
 
C.  Outputs 
1.  Output 1: Enhanced Capacity of Urban Infrastructure 
 
10.  The project will enhance the capacity of crucial urban infrastructure. This output will be 
achieved through implementation of subprojects selected according to pre-established criteria.13 
The subprojects will be developed and prioritized within the framework of the updated regional 
urban plans (output 2) to ensure coherent regional development. Municipalities are required to 
meet certain performance criteria for funding of subprojects, which will create strong incentive to 
improve municipal management and governance (output 3). 
 
11.  Water supply and sanitation. Subprojects relating to water supply and sanitation will 
expand access to such services. Water-supply subprojects will initially focus on rehabilitating 
existing facilities to reduce leaks, before expanding the system. They will adopt energy-efficient 
pumps which will be piloted under TA for energy efficiency improvement. Sanitation subprojects 
will emphasize better design and maintenance of septic tanks, as introduction of a sewer 
network  is  premature.  Design  and  management  of  the  subprojects  will  take  into  account 
women’s requirements since they tend to fetch water and manage sanitation facilities for the 
whole family.

12.  Solidwaste  management.  Subprojects  for  solid-waste  management  will  improve 
collection and disposal of solid waste. They will be accompanied by awareness campaigns for 
the 3Rs (reduce-reuse-recycle). Primary collection will be mostly outsourced to community-
based organizations (CBOs) or nongovernment organizations.14 Women will be encouraged to 
participate in awareness campaign and CBOs. Opportunities for private sector participation and 
registration with the Clean Development Mechanism will be explored, particularly if disposal 
involves composting. To exploit economies of scale and nurture inter-municipality cooperation, 
the project will promote the sharing of treatment and disposal facilities among municipalities. 
 
13.  Energy efficiency program. Subprojects in the energy efficiency program will reduce 
energy consumption to mitigate CO  emission, and cut energy costs to improve municipal 
2
finances.  The  program  will  focus  on  introducing  energy-efficient  water  pumps  and  solar-
powered streetlights. It will start with detailed energy audits and a pilot program, followed by 
capacity and awareness building among municipalities for an expansion of the pilot program. 
Opportunities  to  register  the  subprojects  with  the  Clean  Development  Mechanism  will  be 
explored. 
 
14.  Urban transport. Subprojects relating to urban transport will focus on infrastructure that 
can directly stimulate local economic activities. In addition to improving key roads, bus and truck 
terminals, and other facilities, a pilot program will be carried out to introduce modern traffic 
management,  such  as  control  of  roadside  parking,  improvement  of  sidewalks,  and  use  of 
signals to boost traffic flow and provide a safer environment for pedestrians. 
 
15.  Drainage.  Subprojects  relating  to  drainage  will  rehabilitate  or  extend  drainage  and 
associated facilities to reduce floods and water logging. This will be accompanied by an initiative 
to  improve  collection  and  disposal  of  solid  waste,  and/or  an  awareness  campaign  on  the 
hazards of dumping solid waste into drains. 
 
16.  Urban revitalization. The project will support a small-scale pilot program to revitalize an 
inner-city area of historic importance and to stimulate local economic activities. This will include 
upgrading  and  relocating  public  infrastructure,  and  restoring  public  buildings  of  historic 
importance. The pilot program will assess detailed implementation and financial requirements 
for an eventual expansion via private sector participation. 
 
2.  Output 2: Improved Urban Planning 
 
17.  The  project  will  support  the  review  and  update  of  urban  development  plans  and 
formulate a framework for coherent regional development. The current DMDP (1995–2015) will 
be  updated  for  the  period  of  2016–2035  in  order  to  reflect  the  continued  socioeconomic 
development of the Dhaka city region. Development plans for pourashavas will be prepared 
and/or updated to ensure consistency with the DMDP. The review will put particular emphasis 
on  protecting  the  urban  environment,  taking  into  account  the  impacts  of  urbanization  and 
industrial activities on water bodies. The subprojects to be supported under the project will be 
prioritized  and  designed  along  the  framework  of  the  DMDP  to  ensure  coherent  regional 
development. To help realize the DMDP, the project will support feasibility studies for future 
projects, including one for a satellite town. Extensive public consultations will ensure public 
participation in developing the DMDP and feasibility studies. RAJUK will be responsible for 
updating  the  DMDP  in  collaboration  with  urban  planners  from  the  Dhaka  city  region’s 
municipalities.  The  joint  exercise  will  nurture  a  culture  of  collaboration  between  planning 
agencies and municipalities. 
                                                 
14 Typically, nongovernment organizations and CBOs recover the costs through collection fees and do not need 
municipal subsidies. The project will support introduction of better contractual agreements and selection processes.

5 
 
3.  Output 3: Strengthened Municipal Management and Capacity 
 
18.  The  project  will  support  municipal  capacity  building  in  the  areas  of  property  tax 
collection, public participation, and urban planning. Public participation will be ensured through 
citizens’ committees with broad representation, including women and the poor. The program will 
build on lessons learned from the UGIIP—that effective improvement of municipal management 
is best achieved when capacity development programs are combined with rigorous performance 
monitoring and performance-based fund allocation. The capacity development programs will be 
aligned with activities to meet the performance criteria.  
 
19.  Pourashavas that were covered by the UGIIP have developed sufficient capacity in core 
areas, and the capacity development program will focus on sustaining these achievements. It 
will boost capacity in other areas such as tax assessment, human resource management, 
public–private partnerships, and energy efficiency. Pourashavas that were not covered by the 
UGIIP will start with core training programs established under the UGIIP, such as tax collection, 
citizen participation, and urban planning. City corporations and urban centers will start with a 
pilot program in selected areas.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Strengthening Regional Planning and Governance 
24.  The  TA  aims  to  streamline  and  strengthen  the  institutional  frameworks  of  regional 
planning and governance. It will (i) review the current legal and institutional frameworks of 
regional  planning  and  governance,  particularly  the  Town  Improvement  Act  (1953);  and 
(ii) propose measures to streamline and strengthen the framework by revisiting mandate and 
functions  of  RAJUK,  and  rationalize  the  system  by  allocating  planning  and  control 
responsibilities to the proper levels. ADB will administer the TA. The total cost of the TA is 
estimated  at  $750,000  equivalent.  ADB  will  provide  a  $675,000  grant  from  its  Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV) and the government will make in-kind contribution to cover 
the balance. RAJUK will be the executing agency for the TA and provide counterpart staff and 
office space. A consulting firm will be engaged to implement the TA, through the quality- and 
cost-based  selection  method  with  a  standard  80:20  scoring  weight.  The  outline  terms  of 
reference is described in the PAM. 
 
B.  Energy Efficiency Improvement 
25.  The  TA  will  (i)  promote  energy  efficiency  and  renewable  energy  programs  among 
municipalities, and (ii) carry out detailed energy audits and implement demonstration programs 
to introduce energy-efficient water pumps and solar-powered streetlights. The results will be 
summarized in a best practice manual, including technical specifications, saved energy and 
CO , better street safety, impact of lower energy costs on municipal finances, and increased 
2
property tax as a result of additional streetlights. The best practice manual will be used in 
awareness campaigns and capacity development, so that the program can be expanded under 
the project or through other fund sources. ADB will administer the TA. The total cost of the TA is 
estimated at $1,700,000 equivalent, of which $1,500,000 will be financed by the Asian Clean 
Energy Fund15 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and administered by 
ADB. The government will make in-kind contributions to cover the balance. LGED will be the 
executing agency and provide counterpart staff and office space to the consultant team. The 
Department of Public Health Engineering will provide technical support for the introduction of 
energy-efficient water pumps. A consulting firm will be engaged for the implementation of the 
TA, through the quality- and cost-based selection method with a standard 80:20 scoring weight. 
The outline terms of reference is described in the PAM.

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
26.  Economic analysis. The economic analysis is conducted for sample subprojects. The 
estimates  of  the  economic  internal  rates  of  return  range  from  20.0%  to  52.9%,  indicating 
sufficiently high economic return. The result is robust against downside risks, including higher 
capital cost, increased operation and maintenance (O&M) cost, decreased benefits, and delays 
in project completion. The result most likely underestimates the benefits, since the projects have 
other benefits that are not easily quantifiable and are not accounted for in the analysis.   
 
27.  Financial analysis. For revenue-generating subprojects, financial analysis is conducted 
by estimating the incremental costs and the revenues over the project’s life. The estimated 
financial internal rates of return range from 2.5% to 7.9% and compare favorably with the 
weighted average cost of capital estimated at 0.9%. Sensitivity analysis with respect to changes 
in cost and revenue assumptions confirms the financial viability and the robustness against 
these downside risks. The assessment of water-supply subprojects shows that an affordable 
tariff can recover O&M costs and debt service.16 For nonrevenue-generating subprojects, the 
analysis focuses on the municipalities' financial capacity to meet the recurrent costs of operating 
and maintaining the developed physical assets in a sustainable manner. The overall financial 
position of each pourashava is projected, reflecting the incremental capital, O&M expenditures, 
revenue through user charges, and debt service. The projected financial position confirms their 
financial capacity to meet O&M costs and other requirements to sustain facilities developed 
under the project.   
 
B.  Governance 
28.  The  LGED  and  most  implementing  agencies  have  experience  in  managing  ADB 
projects, and staff were trained under those projects. The project will provide further training to 
strengthen  their  capacity,  including  financial  management,  procurement,  and  safeguard 
measures. Financial management assessments concluded that the LGED’s and implementing 
agencies’  financial  management  systems  are  satisfactory,  with  adequate  procedures  and 
standard  of  fund  flow,  accounting,  reporting,  and  audit.  The  capacity  of  the  LGED  and 
implementing agencies to carry out proper procurement has been assessed as satisfactory. The 
LGED  and  most  implementing  agencies  have  procurement  experience  in  accordance  with 
ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), and their performance so 
far  has  been  satisfactory.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was 
explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
29.  Citizen participation. Major social issues in pourashavas include weak participation 
and representation of citizens—particularly the poor and women—in pourashava management. 
The UGIIP strengthened citizen participation through the formation of citizens’ committees with 
broad representation. The project will build on the UGIIP, and holding regular meetings of 
citizens’ committees will be one of the performance criteria for funding. Municipal management, 
including selection and design of subprojects as well as urban planning, will be discussed at the 
citizens’ committees to ensure broad public participation. 
                                                 
16 Revenue-generating subprojects, including water-supply subprojects, will be funded by 50% grant and 50% loan. 
The loan will have a 4% interest rate with a 20-year repayment period and a 5-year grace period.

9 
 
30.  Gender. A gender action plan has been developed for the project. The project will help 
reduce gender inequality by ensuring that women’s participation in pourashava management 
through  citizens’  committees  and  consultations  on  urban  planning  reaches  at  least  30%. 
Women will have equal opportunity to participate in project-supported training programs. Efforts 
to reduce wage inequality between men and women, and ensure core labor standards will be in 
place. Awareness-raising campaigns will include women, and they will also be involved in water 
user groups and CBOs for solid-waste management. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
31.  Environmental safeguards. The project is classified as category B in accordance with 
ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  LGED  prepared  initial  environmental 
examinations of sample subprojects, including environmental management plans (EMPs). The 
initial environmental examinations, which will be updated during detailed design, conclude that 
no significant adverse environmental impacts are anticipated and that the subprojects would 
have only small, localized impacts to be mitigated through measures outlined in the EMPs. The 
EMPs  will  be  implemented  by  the  PIUs  and  monitored  by  the  PMCU.  Implementation 
arrangements  ensure  that  the  PMCU  and  PIUs  have  adequate  capacity  to  manage 
environmental impacts through consultants’ support and capacity building. An environmental 
assessment and review framework was also prepared to guide environmental assessment in 
subsequent  subprojects.  The  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  outlines 
requirements  for  project  screening,  classification,  environmental  criteria  for  selection  of 
subprojects, information disclosure, consultation, environmental assessment, development and 
implementation of an EMP, and monitoring and reporting. Improvements to sanitation, solid-
waste management, drainage, and roads will have significant positive environmental impacts in 
these municipalities.  
 
32.  Social safeguards. The project is classified as category B for involuntary resettlement 
and category C for indigenous peoples in accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement. 
Involuntary resettlement impacts are not considered significant. Most land parcels are owned by 
local governments; however, some subprojects require minor land acquisition and involuntary 
resettlement involving either physical or economic displacement, or temporary restrictions to 
land  use.  Draft  resettlement  plans  have  been  prepared  for  sample  subprojects  to  ensure 
compliance with the government's and ADB's policy requirements, and to provide entitlements 
for  affected  persons,  including  special  assistance  measures  for  vulnerable  groups.  A 
resettlement framework has been prepared for future subprojects that details screening and 
categorization, assessment, planning, institutional arrangements and processes to be followed. 
The PMCU will ensure that the PIUs will update the resettlement plans during the detailed 
design stage, if required, and implement the final resettlement plans. Considering the urban 
locations of these subprojects, no impacts on indigenous peoples are expected. Implementation 
arrangements ensure that the PMCU and PIUs have adequate capacity to manage social 
impacts through consultants’ support and capacity building. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
33.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4. Risks are relatively low 
and mitigated to a manageable level. The benefits and impacts of the project are expected to 
outweigh the costs and risks.

10 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Ineffective coordination  A  steering  committee  will  be  established  with  stakeholders  in  central 
between the LGED  government and municipalities. Consultation will continue during project 
(executing agency) and  implementation.  Review  and  update  of  the  DMDP  will  strengthen 
implementing agencies  coordination in selecting subprojects for coherent regional development.  
Inadequate capacity of  Need for additional staff is identified and the government assured early 
implementing agencies  assignment. Adequate staffing of the implementing agency is one of the 
performance criteria before subprojects can start. Some staff were trained 
under the previous project, and those who do not have adequate capacity 
will be trained under the project. 
Rapid urban growth  The subprojects in the initial phase will address immediate needs, and the 
beyond expectation  updated DMDP will facilitate identification and prioritization of subsequent 
subprojects. 
Sustainability of  Many  municipalities  have  improved  local  tax  collection  through  the 
subprojects undermined  previous project, and the proposed project will expand the program to new 
by constrained financial  municipalities. The proposed user charges were found affordable, and 
resources  further consultations will be held before introducing new charges.  
Lack of interest in  Small-scale demonstration programs will be implemented and documented 
widening innovative  to  clarify  benefits  for  municipalities,  followed  by  public  awareness 
subprojects  programs. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, DMDP = Dhaka Metropolitan Development Plan, LGED = Local Government 
Engineering Department. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
 
V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
34.  The government and the LGED have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in the 
PAM and loan documents. The government and the LGED have agreed with ADB on certain 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement. As conditions to the 
disbursement, the government will (i) establish the interministerial steering committee and the 
PMCU, and (ii) appoint the project director and the deputy project directors for the PMCU. 
 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
35.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR76,894,000 to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the City 
Region Development Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the 
rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 
years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
